summary: mice were injected intraperitoneally with LPS in combination with d-GalN. mortality became apparent at 5–6 h, and all mice died by 10 h. d-GalN/LPS administration caused no apparent liver injury in mice. per1 protects mice from d-GalN/LPS-induced liver injury and prolongs survival. WT and Per1/ mice were administered 5 g/kg body weight LPS intraperitoneally. survival was monitored for 24 h (n=15 for each group) IL-1 and IL-6 were significantly higher in Per1/ mice than in WT mice. per1 deficiency increases the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines in the liver. administration of d-GalN/LPS significantly increased the number of KCs in both genotypes. a marked increase was observed in the number of KCs in the livers of Per1/ and WT mice compared with the livers of WT mice. hepatic mRNA levels of F4/80 (a) and CD68 (b) were measured by quantitative RT-PCR. n=5; *P0.05, d-GalN/LPS group versus control group; #P0.05, Per1/ group versus WT group Per1 had no influence on the proliferation or apoptosis of macrophages. per1 deficiency increases hepatic Ccr2 expression and enhances hepatic macrophage migration. increased number of KCs could also be due to enhanced monocyte/macrophage recruitment to the liver. Flow cytometry analysis of surface CD115 and CD11b was used to determine the relative numbers of monocytes in peripheral blood. Ccr2 expression was measured in the livers (b) and peritoneal macrophages (c) significantly rescued d-GalN/LPS-induced liver injury in Per1/ mice. reduced levels of serum ALT and AST in WT and DKO mice compared with those in Per1/ mice. deletion of Ccr2 rescued the abnormal accumulation of KCs in Per1/ mice. a) and AST (b) were measured at 5 h after d-GalN/LPS challenge. PER1 may bind to PPAR- and stabilize the association between PPAR- and the transcription factor on the Ccr2 promoter. the addition of troglitazone or GW9662 did not significantly alter the association between these two proteins.
